Developed by Amber Zaratsian
October 24, 2017

%md

%md

## Demo Technology

### Docker
Docker is an open source technology that makes it easier to create, deploy, and run applications by using containers. A container image is a lightweight exectuable that allows developers to package up all the components needed to make their application run, such as tools, libraries and other dependencies, and ship it out as one package. This ensures that the application will run the same regardless of the environment.

For this demo, I created a `Dockerfile`, which is a text document that contains all the commands a user could call on the command line to assemble an image. The `Docker build` command builds an image from a Dockerfile and a context (set of files).

### Apache Zeppelin
Zeppelin is an open source web-based notebook used for interactive data analysis. Through language interpreters, Zeppelin support multiple languages such as Spark, Python, Scala, Hive, shell and markdown. Specifically designed to integrate well with Spark and Hadoop.
Zeppelin: http://localhost:19090

### Apache Spark
Spark is an open source cluster computing engine for Big Data. It has built-in modules for machine learning, SQL, streaming, and graph processing. Spark is primarily written in Scala, but provides several APIs for programmers: Scala, Python, Java, and R. I use Spark with Python known as PySpark (Spark Python API).

### Sparkling Water/H2O
Sparkling Water = Spark + H2O. H2O is an open source, in-memory, distributed, fast, and scalable machine learning platform that allows users to build machine learning models on big data. H2O provides support for popular programming languages, such as Python, R, and Scala. Sparkling Water gives users the ability to combine the fast, scalable machine learning algorithms of H2O with the capabilites of Spark. For this demo, I'm using **PySparkling: Python + Spark + H2O**

### Apache Superset (incubating)
Superset is an open source data exploration platform created by Airbnb. Intuitive and code-free allowing users to quickly create visualizations and dashboards. In preparation, I used PySpark to make some transformations to the loan data and loaded this data into a local SQLite3 database on my Docker container. In Superset, I connect to this database. 
Superset: http://localhost:18088

### Flask
Flask is a web framework in Python. In this demo, I use Flask to deploy my machine learning model in production as an API to enable real-time predictions.

msg.data:
Demo Technology

Docker

Docker is an open source technology that makes it easier to create, deploy, and run applications by using containers. A container image is a lightweight exectuable that allows developers to package up all the components needed to make their application run, such as tools, libraries and other dependencies, and ship it out as one package. This ensures that the application will run the same regardless of the environment.

For this demo, I created a Dockerfile, which is a text document that contains all the commands a user could call on the command line to assemble an image. The Docker build command builds an image from a Dockerfile and a context (set of files).

Apache Zeppelin

Zeppelin is an open source web-based notebook used for interactive data analysis. Through language interpreters, Zeppelin support multiple languages such as Spark, Python, Scala, Hive, shell and markdown. Specifically designed to integrate well with Spark and Hadoop.
Zeppelin: http://localhost:19090

Apache Spark

Spark is an open source cluster computing engine for Big Data. It has built-in modules for machine learning, SQL, streaming, and graph processing. Spark is primarily written in Scala, but provides several APIs for programmers: Scala, Python, Java, and R. I use Spark with Python known as PySpark (Spark Python API).

Sparkling Water/H2O

Sparkling Water = Spark + H2O. H2O is an open source, in-memory, distributed, fast, and scalable machine learning platform that allows users to build machine learning models on big data. H2O provides support for popular programming languages, such as Python, R, and Scala. Sparkling Water gives users the ability to combine the fast, scalable machine learning algorithms of H2O with the capabilites of Spark. For this demo, I’m using PySparkling: Python + Spark + H2O

Apache Superset (incubating)

Superset is an open source data exploration platform created by Airbnb. Intuitive and code-free allowing users to quickly create visualizations and dashboards. In preparation, I used PySpark to make some transformations to the loan data and loaded this data into a local SQLite3 database on my Docker container. In Superset, I connect to this database.
Superset: http://localhost:18088

Flask

Flask is a web framework in Python. In this demo, I use Flask to deploy my machine learning model in production as an API to enable real-time predictions.

paragraphs.text: %md ## Analytics Life Cycle

msg.data: Analytics Life Cycle

paragraphs.text: %md ## I. Business Understanding Lending Club Loan Data ([link](https://www.kaggle.com/wendykan/lending-club-loan-data)) The dataset from Lending Club contains data for all loans issued through the 2007-2015. The dataset contains almost 900k records and 75 features. A data dictionary is also provided. The data contains features of the loan (e.g. loan amount, interest rate, term) and features of the borrower (e.g. employment length, annual income, home ownership). ### **Objective:** **To predict if a person will default on a loan**

msg.data:
I. Business Understanding

Lending Club Loan Data (link)

The dataset from Lending Club contains data for all loans issued through the 2007-2015. The dataset contains almost 900k records and 75 features. A data dictionary is also provided.

The data contains features of the loan (e.g. loan amount, interest rate, term) and features of the borrower (e.g. employment length, annual income, home ownership).

Objective:

To predict if a person will default on a loan

paragraphs.text:
%md

## II. Data Understand

paragraphs.title: Import Packages
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql import functions as F
from pysparkling import *
hc = H2OContext.getOrCreate(spark)
import h2o
from h2o.estimators.gbm import H2OGradientBoostingEstimator

paragraphs.title: Import Data
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

loans = spark.read.csv('/assets/lending_club/loan.csv', header=True, inferSchema=True, quote='"', escape='"', mode='DROPMALFORMED')

# Filter columns
loans = loans[['id', 'loan_status', 'loan_amnt', 'int_rate', 'grade', 'term', 'emp_length', 'purpose', 'home_ownership', 'addr_state', 'annual_inc', 'inq_last_6mths']]

# Print first 5 rows of the DataFrame
loans.show(5)

print ' '
print 'Column Data Types:'

# Print column data types               
loans.dtypes

paragraphs.title: Exploratory Analysis
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print 'Number of records: ' + str(loans.count())

# loan_status categories
print ' '
print 'Loan Status count: '
loans.groupby('loan_status').count().show(truncate=False)

msg.data:
Number of records: 887379
 
Loan Status count: 
+---------------------------------------------------+------+
|loan_status                                        |count |
+---------------------------------------------------+------+
|Fully Paid                                         |207723|
|Default                                            |1219  |
|In Grace Period                                    |6253  |
|Does not meet the credit policy. Status:Fully Paid |1988  |
|Charged Off                                        |45248 |
|Late (31-120 days)                                 |11591 |
|Issued                                             |8460  |

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Clean up loan statuses
loans = (loans.withColumn('loan_status', F.when((loans['loan_status']=='Default') | (loans['loan_status']=='Charged Off'), 'default')
										  .when((loans['loan_status']=='Current') | (loans['loan_status']=='Fully Paid'), 'no default')
										  .otherwise(loans['loan_status'])))

# Filter records for where the loan_status is one of the new categories set above
loans = loans.filter((loans['loan_status']=='default') | (loans['loan_status']=='no default'))

# Lowercase purpose column to standardize values
loans = loans.withColumn('purpose', F.lower(loans['purpose']))

# New record count
print 'Number of records: ' + str(loans.count())

%pyspark

# Min, max, and mean loan amounts
print ' '
print 'Loan Amount Minimum, Maximum, and Average: '
loans.agg(F.min('loan_amnt'), F.max('loan_amnt'), F.mean('loan_amnt')).show()

# Min, max, and mean interest rates
print ' '
print 'Interest Rate Minimum, Maximum, and average: '
loans.agg(F.min('int_rate'), F.max('int_rate'), F.mean('int_rate')).show()

# term categories
print ' '
print 'Term count: '
loans.groupby('term').count().show()

# grade categories
print ' '
print 'Grade count: '
loans.orderBy('grade').groupby('grade').count().show()

# home_ownership categories
print ' '
print 'Home Ownership count: '
loans.groupby('home_ownership').count().show()

# emp_length categories
print ' '
print 'Employment Length count: '
loans.groupby('emp_length').count().show()

# purpose categories
print ' '
print 'Purpose count: '
loans.groupby('purpose').count().sort(F.desc('count')).show()

# inq_last_6mths categories
print ' '
print 'Inquires in the last 6 months count: '
loans.groupby('inq_last_6mths').count().sort('inq_last_6mths').show()

%md

## III. Data Preparation

paragraphs.title: Data Transformations
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Clean up home ownership
loans = (loans.withColumn('home_ownership', F.when((loans['home_ownership']=='OWN_MORTGAGE') |(loans['home_ownership']=='MORTGAGE'), 'OWN')
			  .when(loans['home_ownership']=='RENT', 'RENT')
			  .otherwise('OTHER')))

loans = loans.drop('int_rate').drop('grade')

loans.show(10)

%md

## IV. Modeling & V. Evaluation

The algorithm being used is Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM). GBM produces a prediction model in the form of a forward learning ensemble method. 
[H2O GBM Documentation](http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/data-science/gbm.html)

msg.data:
IV. Modeling & V. Evaluation

The algorithm being used is Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM). GBM produces a prediction model in the form of a forward learning ensemble method.
H2O GBM Documentation

paragraphs.title: Model 1: Preparation
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Convert PySpark DataFrame to an H2O DataFrame
loansHF = hc.as_h2o_frame(loans, framename='loans')

# Convert string variables into factors
string_vars = [i[0] for i in loansHF.types.iteritems() if i[1]=='string']
for var in string_vars:
    loansHF[var] = loansHF[var].asfactor()
    
# Split dataset in to training, testing, and validation
training, testing, validation = loansHF.split_frame([0.7, 0.2], seed=12345)

# Define target variable
target = 'loan_status'

# Define predictors
predictors = loansHF.names[:]
predictors.remove(target)
predictors.remove('id')

paragraphs.title: Model 1: Modeling
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Modeling
gbm_regressor = H2OGradientBoostingEstimator(ntrees=50, max_depth=6, learn_rate=0.1, distribution='bernoulli')

# Train the model
gbm_regressor.train(x=predictors, y=target, training_frame=training, validation_frame=validation)


# Metrics
print gbm_regressor.varimp(True)
print gbm_regressor.accuracy()
print gbm_regressor.confusion_matrix(train = True)
print gbm_regressor.auc(train=True)

# Predictions
gbm_regressor.model_performance(testing)
predictions = gbm_regressor.predict(testing)
predictions.head()

%md

#### Imbalanced Data

The number of defaults is small compared to the total number of loans. By using the data as-is to train the model above, I do not build a very good model to identify those likely to default. 

Let's test undersampling the data and building a model. Undersampling will drop some of the "no default" samples at random to give a balanced dataset with almost equal class distribution.

msg.data:
Imbalanced Data

The number of defaults is small compared to the total number of loans. By using the data as-is to train the model above, I do not build a very good model to identify those likely to default.

Let’s test undersampling the data and building a model. Undersampling will drop some of the “no default” samples at random to give a balanced dataset with almost equal class distribution.

paragraphs.title: Model 2: Preparation
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Create equal split of "default" and "no default" records
number_of_no_defaults = loans.groupBy('loan_status').count().filter(loans['loan_status']=='no default').collect()[0][1]
number_of_defaults    = loans.groupBy('loan_status').count().filter(loans['loan_status']=='default').collect()[0][1]
stratified_ratio      = number_of_defaults / float(number_of_no_defaults)
loans.groupBy('loan_status').count().show()

loans = loans.sampleBy('loan_status', fractions={'default': 1.00, 'no default': stratified_ratio}, seed=4321)
loans.groupBy('loan_status').count().show()

# Convert PySpark DataFrame to an H2O DataFrame
loansHF2 = hc.as_h2o_frame(loans)

# Convert string variables into factors
string_vars = [i[0] for i in loansHF2.types.iteritems() if i[1]=='string']
for var in string_vars:
    loansHF2[var] = loansHF2[var].asfactor()

# Loan Status Distributions
loansHF2["loan_status"].table()

# Split dataset in to training, testing, and validation
training2, testing2, validation2 = loansHF2.split_frame([0.7, 0.2], seed=12345)

# Define target variable
target = 'loan_status'

# Define predictors
predictors = loansHF2.names[:]
predictors.remove(target)
predictors.remove('id')

paragraphs.title: Model 2: Modeling
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Modeling
gbm_regressor2 = H2OGradientBoostingEstimator(distribution='bernoulli', ntrees=5, max_depth=3, learn_rate=0.1)
gbm_regressor2.train(x=predictors, y=target, training_frame=training2, validation_frame=validation2)

# Metrics
print gbm_regressor2.varimp(True)
print gbm_regressor2.accuracy()
print gbm_regressor2.confusion_matrix(train = True)
print gbm_regressor2.auc(train=True)

# Predictions
gbm_regressor2.model_performance(testing2)
predictions2 = gbm_regressor2.predict(testing2)
predictions2.head()

paragraphs.title: Save Model
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

model_path = h2o.save_model(model=gbm_regressor2, path = '/assets/flask_deployment_demo/', force=True)

print model_path

%md

## VI. Deployment

To run the Flask app for this model:
1) Start the Docker command line and run this code:

    /spark/bin/spark-submit --py-files /sparkling-water-2.2.6/py/build/dist/h2o_pysparkling_2.2-2.2.6.zip /assets/flask_deployment_demo/loan_app_demo.py 
    
2) Then in your browser go to http://localhost:15555

msg.data:

To run the Flask app for this model:
1) Start the Docker command line and run this code:

/spark/bin/spark-submit --py-files /sparkling-water-2.2.6/py/build/dist/h2o_pysparkling_2.2-2.2.6.zip /assets/flask_deployment_demo/loan_app_demo.py

2) Then in your browser go to http://localhost:15555
